statement:
[**Theorem.**]{} A compact set in a Hausdorff space is closed.

*Proof.* Let $A$ be a compact set in a Hausdorff space $X$. The case
when $A$ is empty is trivial, so let us assume that $A$ is non-empty.
Using , it follows that each point $y$ in $A^{{\complement}}$ has a
neighborhood $U_y$, which is disjoint to $A$. (Here, we denote the
complement of $A$ by $A^{{\complement}}$.) We can therefore write
$$\begin{aligned}
A^{{\complement}} &=& \bigcup_{y\in A^{{\complement}}} U_y.\end{aligned}$$
Since an arbitrary union of open sets is open, it follows that $A$ is
closed. $\Box$

The above theorem can, for instance, be found in [@kelley] (page 141),
or [@singer] (Section 2.1, Theorem 2).

[9]{} J.L. Kelley, *General Topology*, D. van Nostrand Company, Inc.,
1955. I.M. Singer, J.A.Thorpe, *Lecture Notes on Elementary Topology and
Geometry*, Springer-Verlag, 1967.
